properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and humid airmass continues to push into the Maritimes and will persist into Thursday. Daytime highs over inland areas of Nova Scotia are forecast to be near 30 C Wednesday with overnight lows near 19 degrees providing little relief. Humidex values are expected to reach 36 to 39 Wednesday. Temperatures across the province should begin to cool down late Thursday as a trough of low pressure moves in from the northwest. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T17:24:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-31T01:25:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2963710499.2019
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay, Colchester County North, Hants County, Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County, Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and torrential rain. ### Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T10:59:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-31T02:50:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1611954461.2019
Area: Amqui area, Matap√©dia area, New-Richmond - Bonaventure area, Restigouche - Carleton area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and humid airmass will remain over New Brunswick on Wednesday. Maximum daytime temperatures near 30 degrees will persist over much of New Brunswick on Wednesday, with lows Wednesday night near 19 C providing little relief. Humidex values of 37 to 39 will also persist. Maximum temperatures along the Bay of Fundy, will be somewhat cooler. However, areas slightly inland are still likely to reach heat warning criteria. Temperatures across northwestern portions of the province will cool somewhat on Wednesday as a trough of low pressure begins to move across the region. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T17:29:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-31T01:30:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2099082489.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 9:44 p.m. CST, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to toonie size hail and heavy rain. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain will continue along with brisk northwest winds before coming to an end near midnight. This rainfall is associated with a low pressure system moving slowly northward over southeastern HUdson Bay. A total of 44.3 mm of rain was reported at Peawanuck as of 8.00 PM. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T09:54:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-31T01:55:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3849875027.2019
Area: Peawanuck, Fort Albany
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and humid airmass will remain over Prince Edward Island on Wednesday. Daytime maximum temperatures are expected to reach 30 degrees Wednesday. Overnight lows Wednesday night are expected to fall to near 19 degrees providing little relief from the heat. Maximum humidex values of 35 to 38 are expected. Temperatures across the island should cool down somewhat on Thursday as a trough of low pressure moves in from the northwest. Daytime highs on Thursday are forecast to be around 26 C with humidex values near 33. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T17:27:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-31T01:28:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2959380531.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing heavy rain. An area of thunderstorms over the region is giving frequent lightning and torrential downpours. These storms will continued to be monitored as they track northeastward across our region. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: At 8:03 p.m. MDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to toonie size hail and heavy rain. This line of severe thunderstorms stretches from Lloydminster to Provost and is moving east at 35 km/h. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. A low pressure trough will push eastward across Saskatchewan tonight and Wednesday. As the trough moves through it will continue to trigger thunderstorms, some of which will likely become severe throughout the night as it encounters the warm, humid, and unstable airmass already in place. The severe thunderstorm watch has ended for Regina as well as points west and south, but has been expanded to include regions from Moosomin through Kamsack. ### Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T13:59:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-31T03:20:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3460487630.2019

Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
